I would say my biggest challenge was figuring out a system that made the entire first year more manageable.  There were a few times where I either forgot to read something or nearly missed an assignment because I would refer to the syllabus but there would periodically be updates on Moodle (similar to BlackBoard) or you might miss something in class and as a result miss an important piece of information, etc.  I went through a lot of trial and error but eventually what worked for me was the following:  Kept a regular schedule, Mon-Fri, regardless of your classes.  I would get to campus around 7am and stay until about 3:30 or 4.  I would try to do very little work on the weekends, unless there was a big project (which was unavoidable at times). The regular schedule kept me honest and it helped to keep the separation between school and the rest of my life. This will have to be modified for night classes obviously (just a longer day).  Printed out all of my syllabi and kept separate folders and notebooks (for notes) for each course.  I kept a separate planner for assignments and went in and filled everything in for the entire semester, updating as needed.  This was huge because it allowed me to see big picture the work load rather than just on my phone or an online calendar.  I also tried to limit computer use in class and take hand notes (which has been proven to increase memory and retention) unless of course I was in a stats class or quantitative class.  Financial Accounting was the single worst experience of my life.  I would take full advantage of the open office hours.  If you aren‚Äôt 100% sure on anything in the class it will come back to crush you on the mid-term and final.  I didn‚Äôt do that and almost failed, it was by far and away my worst class. Everything builds on top of everything else so it‚Äôs really crucial that you understand everything.  The same goes for Managerial Accounting. You don‚Äôt realize it, but Dr. Mitchell is actually teaching you the entire capital assets pricing method but breaking it up into its constituent parts. I would take advantage of as many Career resources as possible.  I went to most if not all of the corporate presentations.  It‚Äôs a great opportunity for you to ask questions and connect with people on LinkedIn.  This also includes mock interviews and bringing specific internship postings to your counselor so they can provide you guided and specific advice for plans of attack.  The most rewarding part of the first year was probably just surviving.  Getting through that first semester really gives you the confidence to continue pushing hard in that second semester. Hi Chris,  Let me elaborate my point.¬†  I fully agree that COBOL is highly efficient in record processing and cost effective¬†comparing to Java in CPU cost.¬†  But how many of new labour will choose COBOL as their career? People have so many choices in this era. Young people like to choose web or mobile development which can offer a higher salary. We can easily say the Internet industry can provide more job opportunities than COBOL positions, COBOL applications¬†are more for the existing established shops, though their biz may grow and increase application needs for COBOL, new shops may not choose COBOL as there are so many alternatives.¬†  When it comes to recruitment, enterprises won't pay higher salary just because the talent pool is limited, the application development is to support biz need, salary will be based on biz value of the output, rather than the rareness of the skillset.¬†  Unit cost of CPU are getting cheaper, companies that can afford to run COBOL, usually have less concern on real money expense on hardware. The migration of COBOL to other languages is more costly and risky.¬†  As decision makers, we have to consider not only the functions and cost of one¬†technology, but the sustainability¬†of the people who run it in behind as well. Big market like the US or CHINA still have big pool of COBOL developer, and there are specialized schools training COBOL, other small market won't have a chance to sustain when no people willing to work with COBOL.¬†  COBOL will still last for decades as there are so many mission-critical applications running on it with great complexity, I just don't have confidence that it can attract next generation to work with it.
